title: Penelope's Experiences in Scotland; Being Extracts from the Commonplace Book of Penelope Hamilton
author: Wiggin, Kate Douglas Smith
snippet: "Findingme in such a lamentable state of ignorance, he explained the principleof his own stupid Forth Bridge to me.

title: The Sunday Philosophy Club
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: People did not kill themselves that way; if you wanted to jump, then you went to the Forth Bridge, or the Dean Bridge if you preferred the ground to the water.

title: The Importance of Being Seven
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: Why are you thinking of the Forth Bridge?"

title: The Importance of Being Seven
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: In his case he had always thought of the Forth Bridge, and of its painting; a subject sufficiently devoid of emotional significance to distract one from the temptation of fantasy.

title: Curriculum Vitae: A Volume of Autobiography
author: Spark, Muriel
snippet: My brother, now on his school holidays, was making a model of the Forth Bridge with his Meccano set; it was augmented by various spare parts that my father brought home from his work place, having made them specially with his own hands.

title: Tombstoning
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: The sun slowly baked them in the rusty can of David's car, and roadworks on the Forth Bridge left them stationary for an hour amidst angry drivers, shimmering tarmac and clammy exhaust fumes.

title: Tombstoning
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: Going over the Forth Bridge seemed to lift their spirits.

title: John and Betty's Scotch history visit,
author: Williamson, Margaret. [from old catalog]
snippet: At a place called Queensferry, so named because  Queen Margaret used to land there when on her way from Edinburgh to her abbey of Dunfermline, their train began the crossing of the famous Forth Bridge over the great bay called the Firth of Forth.

title: London days;
author: Warren, Arthur
snippet: The Forth Bridge is yonder" — pointing.

title: Eight lands in eight weeks;
author: Snyder, Marcia Penfield. [from old catalog]
snippet: Anthony's Well and Hermitage ; gathering "whins" or yellow gorse from the rocky banks, and catching glimpses of the wide-spreading Forth, at one point even descrying a dozen miles away a speck against the sky, which means that wonderful construction of cantilevers  known as the Forth Bridge.

title: European days and ways,
author: Rusling, James Fowler
snippet: They tramped about the streets with thick shoes and woolen clothing, and went off on excursions to Arthur's Seat, the Firth of Forth Bridge, Abbotsford, and the like attractive points, on tops of omnibuses, chatting gayly, both men and women, though some did condescend to carry umbrellas and lap-robes.

title: Addresses and letters of travel,
author: Nye, Stephen Girard
snippet: Having finished the castle, we boarded one of the many coaches that run to the famous Forth Bridge, nine miles away.

title: With the tourist tide,
author: Cooke, Arthur Bledsoe
snippet: To the northwest the I^ew Town stretches over its hills sloping to the Water of Leith, and far beyond it the Forth Bridge lists its giant girders above the tree-tops.

title: Cruciform Mark. The strange story of Richard Tregenna, etc
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: They hailed the chars-a-bancs and cabs, and droveindustriously to Rosslyn, the Forth Bridge, Holyrood, andArthur's Seat—anywhere and everywhere.

title: Bonnie Hills o'Hame, and other gems. [Verses.]
author: Scott, William
snippet: From the west gate, looking west, you seea large public park, with a long avenue between two rowsof trees, and Fettes CoUege, whde in the distance, andsouth of the Forth Bridge, is seen Corstorphine Hill,where Prince Charlie's troops rested before the battle ofPrestonpans.

title: By Shamrock and Heather. [A tale.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: ' I was thinking of going to the Forth Bridge, so ifI'm not back at my usual time, you'll know what isdetaining me.'

title: By Shamrock and Heather. [A tale.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: It's too cold for a drive, but wecould take the train and go and see the Forth Bridge,provided the idea strikes her fancy.'

title: In the Western Highlands of Scotland, and holiday notes at Scarborough
author: Cowley, Percy Tunnicliff.
snippet: I hada very good view of the Forth Bridge, a marvel ofarchitectural engineering skill.
